quote: There is nothing more deceptive than an obvious fact.
It is a capital mistake to theorize before one has data.
My name is Sherlock Holmes. It is my business to know what other people do not know.
I never make exceptions. An exception disproves the rule.
When you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.
The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes.
Mediocrity knows nothing higher than itself, but talent instantly recognizes genius.
Education never ends, Watson. It is a series of lessons, with the greatest for the last.
I am not a whole-souled admirer of womankind.
You see, but you do not observe. The distinction is clear.
The game is afoot.
Crime is common. Logic is rare.
What one man can invent, another can discover.
I have a turn both for observation and for deduction.
I have frequently gained my first real insight into the character of parents by studying their children.
I never guess. It is a shocking habit,—destructive to the logical faculty.
Data! Data! Data! I can’t make bricks without clay.
You know my methods, Watson.
I am a brain, Watson. The rest of me is a mere appendix.
It has long been an axiom of mine that the little things are infinitely the most important.
My mind rebels at stagnation. Give me problems, give me work, give me the most abstruse cryptogram or the most intricate analysis, and I am in my own proper atmosphere.
There is nothing like first-hand evidence.
The most dangerous criminal is the one who is technologically advanced. He knows what he is doing.
To a great mind, nothing is little.
The temptation to form premature theories upon insufficient data is the bane of our profession.
It is not enough to say that an author does not misrepresent the facts; he must represent them.
There is nothing more important than trifles.
What one man can invent another can discover.
The most difficult crime to track is the one which is purposeless.
Elementary, my dear Watson.
